messages.content: Изучи, пожалуйста, инструкцию и помоги сделать превосходный проект, готовый к запуску согласно инструкции

Здравствуйте! Я готов помочь вам с вашим проектом.

Для начала мне нужно ознакомиться с инструкцией. Я вижу, что у вас открыт файл `GEMINI.md`. Это и есть инструкция, которую мне следует изучить?

thoughts.subject: Considering the Instructions
thoughts.description: I've zeroed in on the instruction file. It looks like `GEMINI.md` is the one. Time to pore over its contents and understand the user's intent to start the project.

thoughts.subject: Reading the File's Content
thoughts.description: I've successfully read `GEMINI.md`. Now, I'm analyzing the content to grasp the user's objectives. Next, I must formulate a strategic plan. Once I have the strategic plan, I must communicate it to the user.

toolCalls.name: read_file

response.output:
Role Definition:
You are a highly skilled full-stack Bitrix websites developer with 15+ years of experience specializing in complex, high-performance websites. You possess expert-level knowledge in:

Technical Expertise:
Bitrix core architecture, themes development, modules development
PHP, HTML5, JavaScript (ES6+), CSS3, MySQL optimization
Bitrix security best practices, caching solutions, performance optimization
Enterprise-level Bitrix deployments
We're developing website using CMS version: 1С-Битрикс: Управление сайтом 25.550.100

Design & UX Expertise:

Modern web design trends and best practices
B2B Ecommerce UX/UI design principles
Copywriting and SEO strategy implementation
WCAG 2.1 accessibility guidelines compliance
Screen reader optimization

Code Requirements:

Provide clean, well-documented code following industry standards.
Provide well-structured code and directories organisation according to the best Bitrix development practices.
Include comprehensive error handling and detailed comments
Implement responsive design with cross-browser compatibility
Support accessibility features throughout all solutions
Follow semantic HTML5 and BEM CSS methodology
Provide modern, clean and compitable code to the latest PHP, Bitrix  versions
Use ‘edsys’ prefix where needed (short site name).

Mobile-First & Responsive Design Philosophy:

Always design and code mobile-first, starting with 375px viewport
Utilize CSS techniques that minimize or eliminate media queries:
Prefer relative units (rem, em, %, vw, vh, vmin, vmax) over fixed pixels
Implement fluid layouts using Flexbox and CSS Grid with auto-fit/auto-fill
Use CSS functions: clamp(), min(), max(), calc() for adaptive sizing
Leverage intrinsic web design principles for natural responsiveness
Apply container queries where appropriate for component-based responsive behavior

Create layouts that adapt fluidly across all screen sizes without breakpoint dependencies
Implement progressive enhancement from mobile to desktop experience
Ensure touch-friendly interfaces with appropriate tap targets (minimum 44px)
Optimize performance for mobile networks and devices
Maintaining a consistent style throughout the project
Unhandled errors are not allowed
Deprecated methods are not allowed
Unused functions are not allowed

Specific Technical Constraints:
Create SEO-optimized page sections using semantic HTML
Use unique BEM class names by section to avoid conflicts with Bitrix. Add “edsys” prefix to classes, functions and so on
Avoid hover transform: translateY effects
Do not specify font sizes or font family names
Include all image attributes (width, height, loading, alt, etc.)
Use Phosphor icons with ph-thin weight class (https://unpkg.com/@phosphor-icons/web@2.1.1/src/thin/style.css?ver=2.1.1)
Implement text highlighting effects where appropriate
Ensure cross-browser compatibility
Create adaptive design supporting screens from 375px and up
Handle mobile hover states appropriately (use @media (hover: hover) when needed)
Optimize for fast page load speeds with mobile-first asset loading
Implement CSS custom properties for scalable design systems
Use aspect-ratio property for maintaining proportions across devices

If there is an opportunity to fix bugs or improve design and functionality, before writing modified code, specify what changes you propose to make and ask if I need the changes. Do not fix and change yourself the design and functionality of the code provided for modification . Make only those changes and bug fixes that you are asked to make.

Content Requirements:

Avoid using detailed comments.
Write only production ready comments concerning the certain block of code.

If requests are ambiguous, ask clarifying questions before providing solutions
Focus on Ecommerce B2B, event industry, power distribution, stage equipment, custom solutions context when relevant

Response Format:
Always provide practical, actionable advice with relevant code examples that can be immediately implemented, emphasizing mobile-first approach and demonstrating techniques that reduce media query dependency.
Always provide filenames and names of directories.
Always add version to the file and change the version when make changes in file.
Add author: KW and URI https://kowb.ru
Please answer in English.

## Project Overview

This project is a Bitrix CMS-based e-commerce website for a company called "EDS - Electric Distribution Systems". The website sells professional solutions for power distribution and signal management. The site is built using PHP, with a custom Bitrix template and components. It uses AJAX for a dynamic user experience, including features like adding products to the cart, a newsletter subscription, and contact forms.

## Building and Running

There are no explicit build steps documented in the files. The project seems to be a standard Bitrix installation. To run the project, you would typically need a web server with PHP and a MySQL database, and you would need to configure the Bitrix environment.

**TODO:** Document the exact steps for setting up a local development environment.

## Development Conventions

*   The project uses a custom Bitrix template located in `/local/templates/edsy_main/`.
*   Custom components are located in `/local/components/eds/`.
*   Global PHP functions and event handlers are defined in `/local/php_interface/init.php`.
*   AJAX handlers are located in the `/local/ajax/` directory.
*   The code is written in Russian, including comments and variable names.
*   The project uses jQuery and the Phosphor Icons library.
*   There is a commented-out "Bitrix License Blocker" in `php_interface/init.php`, which suggests that the project might be running on an unlicensed version of Bitrix.

toolCalls.description: Reads and returns the content of a specified file. If the file is large, the content will be truncated. The tool's response will clearly indicate if truncation has occurred and will provide details on how to read more of the file using the 'offset' and 'limit' parameters. Handles text, images (PNG, JPG, GIF, WEBP, SVG, BMP), and PDF files. For text files, it can read specific line ranges.

messages.content:
Okay, I will modify the mobile navigation in `local/templates/edsy_main/header.php`.

Here is the plan:
1.  Remove the "Заказы" (Orders) and "Сравнение" (Comparison) buttons.
2.  Add "Главная" (Home), "Аккаунт" (Account), and "Корзина" (Cart) buttons with appropriate icons and links.
3.  The "Главная" (Home) button will be hidden on the homepage.
4.  Keep the existing "Каталог" (Catalog) and "Избранное" (Favorites) buttons.
5.  Update the file version from 1.1 to 1.2 as per the instructions.

I will now apply these changes.

toolCalls.description:
Replaces text within a file. Replaces a single occurrence. This tool requires providing significant context around the change to ensure precise targeting. Always use the read_file tool to examine the file's current content before attempting a text replacement.
      
      The user has the ability to modify the `new_string` content. If modified, this will be stated in the response.
      
      Expectation for required parameters:
      1. `file_path` MUST be an absolute path; otherwise an error will be thrown.
      2. `old_string` MUST be the exact literal text to replace (including all whitespace, indentation, newlines, and surrounding code etc.).
      3. `new_string` MUST be the exact literal text to replace `old_string` with (also including all whitespace, indentation, newlines, and surrounding code etc.). Ensure the resulting code is correct and idiomatic and that `old_string` and `new_string` are different.
      4. `instruction` is the detailed instruction of what needs to be changed. It is important to Make it specific and detailed so developers or large language models can understand what needs to be changed and perform the changes on their own if necessary. 
      5. NEVER escape `old_string` or `new_string`, that would break the exact literal text requirement.
      **Important:** If ANY of the above are not satisfied, the tool will fail. CRITICAL for `old_string`: Must uniquely identify the single instance to change. Include at least 3 lines of context BEFORE and AFTER the target text, matching whitespace and indentation precisely. If this string matches multiple locations, or does not match exactly, the tool will fail.
      6. Prefer to break down complex and long changes into multiple smaller atomic calls to this tool. Always check the content of the file after changes or not finding a string to match.
      **Multiple replacements:** If there are multiple and ambiguous occurences of the `old_string` in the file, the tool will also fail.

toolCalls.name: replace

args.instruction: Update the file version from 1.1 to 1.2.

thoughts.subject: Revising the File
thoughts.description: I've already swapped out the mobile navigation. The next step is updating the version number inside that file. Right now, I'm getting ready to reread the `header.php` file to make sure I have the most up-to-date version before making the change.

thoughts.subject: Narrowing the Focus
thoughts.description: I'm refining my approach. I realized I was being too broad in my previous attempts. Now, I'm zeroing in on a smaller portion of the `header.php` file to pinpoint the version number. This will make the replacement more precise. I've confirmed the exact string I need to change: `* @version 1.1`. Time to update!

messages.content:
The mobile navigation has been updated in `/local/templates/edsy_main/header.php` and the file version has been changed to 1.2.

Is there anything else I can help you with?

thoughts.subject: Concluding the Task's Status
thoughts.description: The modification to the mobile navigation, specifically in `local/templates/edsy_main/header.php`, is finished. I have also updated the version number within that file to reflect this change. The project is effectively completed.

messages.content:
Все супер, но сейчас появился 2-й ряд в котором только одна кнопка. Получается верстка поехала. Посмотри скриншот @image.png. Сделай чтобы css grid-template-columns: repeat(4, 1fr); менялся динамично на grid-template-columns: repeat(5, 1fr); на всех страницах кроме главной
--- Content from referenced files ---<image/png>
--- End of content ---

You are right, the layout broke because the grid was set for 4 items. My apologies.

I will fix this by dynamically adjusting the number of columns in the grid. On the homepage, it will be a 4-column grid, and on all other pages, it will be a 5-column grid. This will ensure the navigation bar looks correct on all pages.

I will apply this fix to the `local/templates/edsy_main/header.php` file.

thoughts.subject: Diagnosing Navigation Bar Issue
thoughts.description: I've isolated the problem: the mobile navigation bar's CSS, designed for four items, is now misaligned on most pages because five menu items are present. I need to adjust the CSS to accommodate the extra element and ensure proper visual presentation.

thoughts.subject: Analyzing Dynamic CSS Adjustments
thoughts.description: I'm now zeroing in on the implementation. My plan is to add inline styling via PHP, specifically within the `header.php` file, so I don't need a new CSS file. The logic will involve checking the number of navigation items, using a PHP conditional to inject the appropriate `grid-template-columns` value. I'll need to locate the existing CSS definition first, though, to ensure compatibility.

thoughts.subject: Crafting Dynamic CSS Rules
thoughts.description: I'm now outlining the exact PHP code to implement the dynamic CSS. I'll utilize `GetCurPage()` to detect the current page. If it's the homepage, the grid columns will be set to `repeat(4, 1fr)`. Otherwise, on all other pages, the value will be `repeat(5, 1fr)`. This should cleanly resolve the wrapping issue. I'll inject this directly into the `<nav>` tag using a conditional statement, and testing will be a breeze.

thoughts.subject: Formulating Dynamic Grid Logic
thoughts.description: I'm now building out the PHP code. I'll insert a conditional check using `$APPLICATION->GetCurPage(false)` to determine if it's the homepage.  Based on this, I'll set the `$gridCols` variable to either 4 or 5. Then, this value will be injected directly into the inline style of the `edsys-mobile-nav__grid` div, within the `grid-template-columns` property, ensuring proper spacing. I must also correct the PHP in the conditional statement to ensure the homepage shows the correct icons.

thoughts.subject: Confirming Grid Column Count
thoughts.description: I've reviewed the item count on the homepage. My initial assessment had an error; the homepage also displays five navigation items, *not* four. This necessitates a slight adjustment to my previous PHP implementation. I'll need to remove the conditional statement that hides the "Главная" icon, ensuring all five items are always present. With this adjustment, all pages will use `repeat(5, 1fr)`, which simplifies the code. The inline CSS solution remains optimal. I'll test it across multiple pages.

thoughts.subject: Refining Dynamic Column Count
thoughts.description: I'm now implementing the PHP code in `header.php`. The core logic, leveraging `$APPLICATION->GetCurPage(false)`, will set `$gridCols` to either 4 or 5 based on the page. I'll inject the `$gridCols` value into the inline `grid-template-columns` style of the navigation grid, ensuring proper responsiveness across the site. I'll need to confirm that my changes render correctly.

thoughts.subject: Adjusting Inline CSS Injection
thoughts.description: I'm now incorporating the inline CSS into `header.php`. The core idea remains the same: use a PHP conditional, based on the current page, to set the `grid-template-columns` property dynamically. However, I have identified a minor inconsistency, and I'll test the updated version shortly.

thoughts.subject: Finalizing CSS Injection
thoughts.description: I'm now fully ready to implement the dynamic column count. I'll modify the `header.php` file, targeting the specific navigation HTML block. The PHP logic is confirmed: using `$APPLICATION->GetCurPage(false)` and a conditional ternary operator for `$gridCols`, I'll determine the correct `grid-template-columns` value (4 or 5). Then, I'll inject that value into the `style` attribute of the appropriate div. My testing is now planned.

thoughts.subject: Implementing Dynamic Grid Columns
thoughts.description: I'm now in the process of implementing the code modifications to `header.php`. I have devised a plan to replace the original navigation HTML with a modified version that includes inline CSS for dynamic grid column adjustments. I'll test the changes.

toolCalls.name: read_file

toolCalls.description: Reads and returns the content of a specified file. If the file is large, the content will be truncated. The tool's response will clearly indicate if truncation has occurred and will provide details on how to read more of the file using the 'offset' and 'limit' parameters. Handles text, images (PNG, JPG, GIF, WEBP, SVG, BMP), and PDF files. For text files, it can read specific line ranges.

toolCalls.name: replace

args.new_string:
GetCurPage(false) === '/'; $gridCols = $isHomePage ? 4 : 5; ?>
Главная Корзина Избранное Аккаунт
args.instruction: Dynamically adjust the grid columns for the mobile navigation. Set 4 columns for the homepage and 5 columns for all other pages to fix the layout issue.

thoughts.subject: Reflecting On The Grid
thoughts.description: I've finally nailed down the grid layout problem. Now, I need to shift my focus to updating the file version. The current version is 1.2, so I must change it to 1.3. A simple task, but essential for the update.

messages.content:
I have applied the fix. The mobile navigation grid should now display correctly with 4 items on the homepage and 5 items on all other pages. The file version has been updated to 1.3.

Let me know what you'd like to do next.

thoughts.subject: Reporting Task Completion
thoughts.description: The mobile navigation grid issue is resolved, as confirmed by `local/templates/edsy_main/header.php`. I've also bumped the version number to 1.3 within the same file. Now, I'm ready to relay the completion and await further instructions.

messages.content: Сделай также кнопку Аккаунт динамично меняющейся в зависимости от статуса посетителя. Если не залогинен, то кнопка должна отображаться как "Войти", если залогинен, то "Аккаунт"

Of course. I will make the "Account" button dynamic to show "Login" for guests and "Account" for logged-in users, just like in the desktop header.

I will now modify the `local/templates/edsy_main/header.php` file.

thoughts.subject: Contemplating Button Behavior
thoughts.description: I'm currently focused on the conditional rendering of the "Аккаунт" button in the mobile navigation. It's clear that the button's label needs to change dynamically based on the user's login status. I've sketched out the two states: "Войти" for unauthenticated users and "Аккаунт" for logged-in ones. The next step is to figure out the best way to detect the authorization state within the component.

thoughts.subject: Replicating Login Logic
thoughts.description: Now, I'm working to implement the dynamic button behavior in the mobile navigation, mirroring the existing logic used for the desktop version. I've pinpointed the relevant section in `header.php` and the account button's HTML. The goal is to wrap the account button with a PHP conditional, much like the desktop header. I'm now drafting the PHP code and preparing the strings for the automated file modification.

thoughts.subject: Implementing File Replacements
thoughts.description: I'm now generating the `old_string` and `new_string` parameters, key for the automated file updates. The focus is to precisely target the mobile navigation's account button. I've taken the existing mobile button HTML and built the `new_string` using the `if ($USER->IsAuthorized())` conditional. Now I will build the `old_string` for the auto-replacer.

thoughts.subject: Crafting the Replacement Strings
thoughts.description: I'm now deeply immersed in assembling the `old_string` and `new_string` for the automated file modification. The plan is to replace the existing mobile account button with a PHP conditional block. I'm focusing on the precise markup, making sure the replacement targets the exact `<nav>` block to avoid unintended consequences and ensure proper syntax and the correct links. The `old_string` construction is finished and the `new_string` is built from the authorized and unauthorized states.

thoughts.subject: Refining File Strings
thoughts.description: I'm now carefully inspecting the `old_string` and `new_string` values, after ensuring the links were correct. I am meticulously reviewing the code snippets to verify that the spacing, capitalization, and class names align with the existing HTML structure. The goal is to minimize the potential for errors during the automated replacement phase, specifically for the mobile navigation section. I am now double-checking the code blocks.

thoughts.subject: Confirming File Replacement
thoughts.description: I'm now fully confident that the `old_string` and `new_string` are accurate. I'm preparing to read `header.php`, carefully review its content to confirm the mobile navigation's position, and then execute the file replacement using the built strings. Afterward, I will proceed to the next step, versioning the file update.

toolCalls.description: Reads and returns the content of a specified file. If the file is large, the content will be truncated. The tool's response will clearly indicate if truncation has occurred and will provide details on how to read more of the file using the 'offset' and 'limit' parameters. Handles text, images (PNG, JPG, GIF, WEBP, SVG, BMP), and PDF files. For text files, it can read specific line ranges.

The "Account" button in the mobile navigation is now dynamic. It will display "Войти" (Login) for guests and "Аккаунт" (Account) for logged-in users. The file version has been updated to 1.4.

What is the next task?
